pageData.text: Do you like spicy foods? Most spicy food contains the molecule capsaicin, derived from chilis, which trigger the temperature receptors on the tongue causing a painful burning sensation. The hotness of chilis is based on the amount of capsaicin they contain and is measured in units called Scovilles. The Scoville scale was originally based on the number of times you would need to dilute an extract from the chili before you could no longer detect the capsaicin. Jalapeños can be as low as 3500 on the Scoville scale while the hottest chili as of 2020, the Carolina Reaper, can measure up to 2.2 million Scovilles1. This means that you could have 1 part extract and 2.2 million parts water and still detect the spice.There are many hypotheses about why chili plants evolved capsaicin, but one possible reason may have to do with the fact that mammals can taste and are affected by capsaicin, while birds are not. Capsaicin deters mammals from eating chilis, which have fragile seeds that are damaged by chewing. Birds swallow the seeds whole and excrete them intact over large distances, making them ideal for dispersing chili seeds.
1Buchanan, M. (2020, January 8). Some like it hot. Nature News.https://www.nature.com/articles/s41567-019-0766-3

pageData.subTitle: What is a microbe?
pageData.text: Microorganisms, also called microbes, are organisms that are so small they are typically not individually visible without the aid of a microscope. Under favorable conditions, an individual microbe may multiply on a solid surface, forming a discrete mound called a (the white structures in Figure 1). Sometimes these colonies can be seen without the aid of a microscope; for example, when there is visible bread mold, what is seen is a colony, not an individual. There are two types of cellular microbes: prokaryotes and eukaryotes.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Tiny dome-like bacteria colonies growing on agar medium.

pageData.subTitle: What are prokaryotes?
pageData.text: Prokaryotic microbes are unicellular (single-celled) organisms. They lack nuclear membranes and generally have circular chromosomes instead of the linear chromosomes typically found in eukaryotes. Prokaryotes do not have membrane-bound organelles. When they carry out the reactions of respiration or photosynthesis, they must do so without the extensive subcellular structures devoted to these energy transformations in eukaryotes. Organisms found in the domains Archaea and Bacteria are prokaryotic. Pseudomonas fluorescens, is the bacteria species used in this investigation.

pageData.subTitle: What are eukaryotes?
pageData.text: Eukaryotic microbes may be unicellular or multicellular. The cells of eukaryotes have membrane-bound organelles. Chromosomes residing in the nucleus are separated from the rest of the cell by a nuclear membrane. Organisms found in the domain Eukarya are eukaryotes and include animals, plants, protists, and fungi. A fungus is a heterotrophic eukaryote with cell walls made of chitin, a polysaccharide. Fungi absorb nutrients from the environment, secreting digestive enzymes to break down materials before they are absorbed. The fungi Penicillium notatum (a mold) will be used in this investigation.

pageData.subTitle: How can microbes be controlled?
pageData.text:
Because some microbes are pathogenic (disease causing), controlling their growth can be extremely important. While some control mechanisms kill microbes, others inhibit their growth without killing them. Agents that kill microorganisms have the suffix (for example, bactericidal or fungicidal). Agents that inhibit the growth of microorganisms have the suffix (for example, bacteriostatic or fungistatic). Antimicrobial agents may function in various ways. Some common modes of control are:
  • Inhibition of cell wall synthesis
  • Disruption of the plasma membrane
  • Inhibition of protein synthesis
  • Denaturation of proteins
  • Inhibition of nucleic acid synthesis
  • Inhibition of essential metabolite synthesis

pageData.subTitle: Spices
pageData.text: Spices are plant parts that are dried and used for flavoring, coloring, or preserving food. These parts, which may be seeds, fruits, roots, or bark, often contain volatile oils. (Herbs are plant leaves used for the same purposes as spices.) Throughout history, spices have served many purposes. They have been used in food preparation, embalming and mummification, the production of fragrances, and as medication.
Although only a few spices are bactericidal/fungicidal, many more are bacteriostatic/fungistatic. There are 7 spices or spice blends in this kit:

1. are prepared from the dried flower buds of the clove plant Syzygium aromaticum, an evergreen tree indigenous to the Moluccas, also known as the Spice Islands.
  2. is the most utilized spice in the world. It is prepared from the berries of an evergreen climbing vine, Piper nigrum. Probably native to southwestern India, black pepper is now cultivated in the tropics of both hemispheres.
  3. are fruits produced by various plants in the genus Capsicum, native to the Americas. Chili powder is a blend of ground chili peppers along with other spices and flavor enhancers, such as cumin, oregano, garlic, cloves, allspice, onion, and salt.
  4. is native to Central Asia. It is of the plant genus Allium, as are many species of onions. The bulb of the garlic plant is the portion that is most commonly eaten and used as a spice.
  5. is prepared from seeds of the Cuminum cyminum plant. This plant is native to the Mediterranean region and also eastward into India.
  6. is prepared from dried peppers, such as bell peppers and chili peppers. The blend of peppers used to make paprika may differ based on the region in which it is produced.
  7. is obtained from the inner bark of trees of the plant genus Cinnamomum. The variety of cinnamon known as true cinnamon is native to Sri Lanka.

pageData.subTitle: Control Groups in Experiments
pageData.text: In scientific experiments, there are often . These groups are treated the same way as the experimental groups except they are not exposed to the variable being tested (in this experiment, the type of spice and type of microbe). There are two different types of control groups: positive and negative.

The researcher does not expect to see any effect in the <button class='glossary-text'>negative control group</button>. For example, in a medical trial, a negative control group might be a placebo group, which received a treatment (e.g., a sugar pill) resembling a drug but containing no medicinal substances. The researcher would not expect the negative control group to have a change in condition because they would not receive the actual drug. The researcher would then compare the condition of the placebo group to that of a group given the drug. If both groups showed a change in condition, then the drug may not work; however, if only the drugtreated group showed a change in condition, this may be evidence that the drug is effective.

The researcher does expect to see a specific effect in the <button class='glossary-text'>positive control group</button>. For example, when testing for the presence of a certain chemical, a researcher will run the test with a known material containing that chemical to ensure the test is working properly. If this test does not give a positive result, then the researcher knows the test is flawed and will not produce reliable results. If the test does produce a positive result, then the researcher knows that the test is working and will conduct the test on the material of unknown composition.

pageData.subTitle: Media preparation
pageData.text: In this investigation, all (singular, medium), a substance where bacteria can grow, were prepared in advance using plate count agar with spices or spice blends added where appropriate. Plate count agar is a general—purpose medium, meaning that it can support the growth of many types of microbes (including bacteria and fungi). Plate count agar contains various nutrients dissolved in water and solidified with agar, a gelatinous material derived from seaweed.

All media were prepared in the same manner, with each containing a different spice or spice blend (or no spice or spice blend for the negative control medium). The media were then <button class='glossary-text'>autoclaved</button> —heated to a very high temperature under pressure—resulting in <button class='glossary-text'>sterile</button> media free of any living organisms. The media were then allowed to cool and solidify, and left sealed. The media will need to be re-melted and poured into sterile Petri dishes as part of the preparation process for this investigation.

This stage of preparation must be conducted using <button class='glossary-text'>aseptic technique</button>—a set of procedures for handling microbes and experimental tools that is aimed at avoiding contamination. Aseptic technique includes the preparation of sterile media and disinfection of work areas to greatly reduce the number of microbes present. Unless aseptic technique is employed, accidental contamination of the sample with the investigator’s microbes or microbes present in airborne dust may occur. The investigator may also be exposed to potentially dangerous microbes.

Once the agar has solidified, it is ready for —the addition of microbes to the medium. The result of inoculation—microbes growing in or on the medium—is called a Figure 2 below shows a freshly inoculated plate, followed by the same plate viewed on subsequent days. Lids are removed for photographic purposes only. NEVER fully remove the lids when inoculating media.

Prepare 12 agar plates (3 of each type) as follows:
  1. Slightly loosen (but do not remove) the cap of the bottle of plate count agar.
  2. Place the bottle in the microwave.
  3. Heat the bottle at 70% power for 30 seconds. While it is heating, monitor the agar at all times to ensure that it does not boil out of the bottle.
  4. Using a heat-resistant glove, potholder, or oven mitt, pick up the bottle and gently swirl the agar.
  5. Continue heating the agar for 10-second intervals with gentle swirling at the end of each time until the agar is completely melted.
  6. Allow the bottle to cool (still warm to the touch but not cool enough for the agar to solidify).
  7. Remove the cap from the agar.

A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before beginning this investigation, you will need to prepare disinfectant and agar plates of the 4 media types. In activity 1, you will inoculate 1 plate of each media type with P. fluorescens and P. notatum. Then, allow the plates to incubate for 4 days. After 4 days, you will observe any plate growth and score the experimental plate growth against the growth on the controls. Finally, you will score card photographs for microbial growth.

data.title: Aseptic technique
data.content: A set of procedures for handling microbes and experimental tools that is aimed at avoiding contamination

data.title: Autoclaved
data.content: Heated to a very high temperature under pressure for the purpose of sterilization

data.title: Black pepper
data.content: A spice prepared from the the berries of Piper nigrum

data.title: Chili pepper
data.content: The fruits of Capsicum which can be ground and combined with other spices to create chili powder

data.title: Cinnamon
data.content: A spice prepared from the inner bark of trees of the plant genus Cinnamomum

data.title: Clove
data.content: A spice prepared from the dried flower Syzgium aromaticum

data.title: Colony
data.content: An aggregation of cells descended from either a single cell or a small number of closely-adhering cells

data.title: Control group
data.content: In a scientific experiment, this is the group that is treated the same as the experimental group but it is not exposed to the variable being tested

data.title: Culture
data.content: The result of growing microbes in predetermined medium under controlled laboratory conditions

data.title: Cumin

data.title: Garlic

data.title: Inoculation
data.content: The process of introducing microbes into culture media to create a culture

data.title: Media
data.content: Substrates within or on which microbes will grow; singular, medium

data.title: Negative control group
data.content: A control group in which a researcher does not expect to see a specific effect

data.title: Paprika
